meta.title: Terms of Service
meta.description: Read our Terms of Service to understand the rules for using the platform, payment conditions, and the rights and responsibilities of users.

content.value: 1. Website — the website located at the address of this website, through which the Seller provides services electronically.

4. Customer — a natural person with full legal capacity, and in cases specified by generally applicable regulations, also a natural person with limited legal capacity, a legal person, or an organizational unit without legal personality, granted legal capacity by law, who has entered into or intends to enter into a service contract.
5. Consumer — Art. 221 of the Civil Code: a natural person entering into a legal transaction with the Seller that is not directly related to their business or professional activity.
6. Service Agreement — an agreement regarding a service posted on the Website entered into or to be entered into between the Customer and the Seller through the Website.
7. Service — a service purchased by the Customer through the Website.
8. Order — the Customer's declaration of intent made through the Website regarding the activation of a subscription or trial access, including the payment method and Customer's data.
9. Subscription Form — an electronic service, a form on an electronic medium available on the Website, enabling the submission and fulfillment of the Order.

10. Subscription Activation Time — the time from the moment of purchasing the subscription or activating trial access, after which the Customer receives immediate access to the Website's resources, usually after payment confirmation.
11. Business Day — any day from Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays.

12. Prices — the prices of services on the Website are fixed at a given time and are not affected by any pricing algorithms, regardless of how the Customer accesses the page, the browsers used, or factors such as gender, age, etc.
13. Consumer Rights Act, the Act — the Act of May 30, 2014, on Consumer Rights (Journal of Laws of 2014, item 827, as amended).
14. GDPR — Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of the European Council (of April 27, 2016).

3. 4. We declare that the reviews posted on our site originate from real customers who have purchased and used our services. Reviews were submitted in response to a request sent after confirming that the service was delivered. We undertake all necessary efforts to ensure the authenticity of reviews and to remove any inauthentic entries.
5. Mandatory legal bases for the above provisions: [subsections]

subsections.value: • Directive (EU) 2019/2161 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 November 2019 amending Council Directive 93/13/EEC and Directives 98/6/EC, 2005/29/EC and 2011/83/EU as regards the better enforcement and modernisation of Union consumer protection rules (OJ L 328, 18.12.2019, pp. 7–28).
• Misleading online reviews — consumer experiences based on a study by PBS Sp. z o.o. commissioned by UOKiK, available at https://uokik.gov.pl/aktualnosci.php?news_id=17411.

• Directive 2005/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 May 2005 concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market and amending Council Directives 84/450/EEC, 97/7/EC, 98/27/EC and 2002/65/EC and Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 (OJ L 149, 11.06.2005, pp. 22–39, as amended).

• Commission Notice — Guidelines on the implementation and interpretation of Directive 2005/29/EC concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market (OJ C 526, 29.12.2021, pp. 1–129).

• Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2011 on consumer rights, amending Council Directives 93/13/EEC and 1999/44/EC and repealing Council Directives 85/577/EEC and 97/7/EC (OJ L 304, 22.11.2011, pp. 64–88, as amended).

content.value: 6. Subscription activation on the Website is effected by completing the subscription form and accepting these Regulations. 9. Every data subject is entitled to the following rights: [subsections]

subsections.value: • To access and verify the lawfulness of the processing of personal data for which the Seller maintains a customer database;
• To ascertain the identity and contact details of the Data Controller (and, if applicable, the Data Protection Officer);
• To obtain information on the purposes, scope, methods, and duration of data processing;
• To receive the personal data concerning them in a commonly understandable form;
• To know the source of their data, unless confidentiality obligations apply;
• To request completion, update, correction, temporarily suspend, or erase their personal data if inaccurate, outdated, unlawfully collected, or no longer necessary for the processing purpose.

content.value: 10. Pursuant to item 9, the Customer has the right to access, correct, and request deletion of their personal data. The Data Controller shall promptly comply with such requests, unless otherwise provided by applicable law.

19. Consumer protection provisions, except for Article 558 §1 sentence 2 of the Civil Code, apply to a natural person concluding a contract directly related to their business activity, where the contract’s content shows it is not of a professional nature for that person.

21. Sole proprietors obtain the following rights: [subsections]

subsections.value: • To protection against unfair contract terms;
• To statutory warranty for defects;
• To recourse claims against a previous seller in relation to consumer complaints;
• To withdraw from a distance contract within 14 days.

content.value: 22. Consumer protection provisions in Articles 385¹–³ of the Civil Code on unfair contractual terms apply to natural persons concluding contracts related to their business activity when the contract is not professional in nature.
23. Article 385⁵ of the Civil Code on abusive clauses applies to sole proprietors as of 1 January 2021.
24. After the above changes, sole proprietors still cannot use consumer protection institutions such as local Consumer Ombudsmen or UOKiK.

1. The Website provides services electronically. The condition for entering into a subscription agreement is completing the subscription form to conclude the service agreement. Joining the agreement is voluntary.

2. The service agreement is concluded electronically by allowing the Customer to complete the subscription form on the Website. The agreement is entered into for an indefinite period, with automatic renewal for each billing cycle (monthly or annual), and terminates upon the Customer’s notice. The Customer may cancel the subscription no later than 3 days before the end of the current billing cycle.
3. The service referred to in item 1 is provided under two plans: [subsections]

subsections.value: a. Free Plan, which does not involve any fees.
b. Paid Plan, available upon payment of the recurring fee.

content.value: 4. Orders (subscription activations) may be placed electronically 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The activation process is available at all times.

5. Providing personal data is necessary to complete the subscription activation process. Failure to provide personal data will be considered a withdrawal from concluding the agreement.

6. In accordance with Article 8(2) of the GDPR, the controller takes appropriate measures to verify that a parent or guardian of a child under 16 has given consent to the processing of the child’s personal data.
7. The Customer bears all costs related to Internet access and data transmission in accordance with the rates set by the Internet service provider with whom the Customer has a contract.

8. The subscription renews automatically for the next billing cycle (monthly or annual) unless the Customer cancels it no later than 3 days before the end of the current cycle. Cancellation may be made via the user panel.

1. To conclude a valid and binding service agreement, the Customer selects the services offered on the Website, specifying the number of services to be ordered and, if applicable, the specifications of the ordered services. The Customer then completes the order form, providing data necessary for the Seller to fulfill the order, such as the number of services, delivery location, and preferred payment method, based on the information available on the Website and in these Regulations.

2. A condition for order fulfillment is the provision by the Customer/Business of complete, true, and accurate data enabling verification of the Customer/Business and the service recipient. The Website confirms receipt of the order by sending an email to the address provided during the ordering process, containing a description of the order. In case of incomplete, incorrect, or inconsistent data, the Website will contact the Customer/Business to correct the errors.
3. Registering a Customer Account on the Website is necessary to receive the service and is free of charge.

4. If the service ordered requires individual customization, the Customer must provide, together with the order form, the content necessary to perform the service (e.g., text, graphics, dimensions) in accordance with the technical requirements specified in the service description. The Customer may also choose an appropriate service specification from the variants offered by the Seller.
5. Upon receiving the order, the Seller immediately sends the Customer a confirmation email to the provided address, which also serves as confirmation of the conclusion of the service agreement.

6. Discounts from different promotions may only be combined if expressly permitted in the promotion’s terms. If no provision for combining discounts exists, the Customer may use only one discount (one promotion) per order.

3. In case of order fulfillment issues, such as lack of access to a course or other technical problems, the Customer will be informed without delay, and the issue will be resolved as quickly as possible.

4. The Customer is informed about any additional costs related to the service (e.g., access to additional materials, certificates) that may arise during the order process.

1. In the case of claims related to the service, the Seller is responsible for the compliance of the service with the contract, in accordance with applicable law.

2. The Seller must respond promptly to the Consumer's claim, but no later than 14 calendar days from its receipt. Failure to address the claim within the specified period is deemed as acceptance by the Seller and recognition of the claim as justified.

3. In case of a service defect, the Customer has the right to file a complaint. Complaints should be submitted electronically to the Seller's email address or in writing to the Seller's postal address. If the consumer has difficulties in formulating a complaint, they can submit it using the template provided as Attachment No. 2 to this Agreement. This is for convenience only, and using this template is not a requirement for the effectiveness of the complaint.
4. The Seller is responsible for non-compliance of the service with the contract if identified within two years of the service's execution.
5. The Seller covers the costs associated with removing the defects of the service or re-executing it.

1. In accordance with the law, a Customer who is a Consumer, pursuant to Article 27 of the Act of May 30, 2014 (Journal of Laws 2014, item 827, as amended) on Consumer Rights, has the right to withdraw from a distance contract without providing a reason.

2. According to Article 38, point 13 of the Consumer Rights Act – "on the provision of digital content not stored on a tangible medium, where the performance of the service started with the explicit consent of the consumer before the withdrawal period and after the entrepreneur informed the consumer of the loss of the right to withdraw from the contract." – in such a case, the right to withdraw does not apply.
3. The right to withdraw from the contract is available within 14 calendar days from the conclusion of the contract.

4. When the Consumer withdraws from the contract, the contract is considered non-concluded, and the Consumer is released from any obligations. The mutual services provided should be returned in an unchanged condition, unless a change was necessary within the scope of ordinary management. The return should occur immediately, no later than fourteen days.

5. A Consumer may withdraw from the contract by submitting a statement using the form attached as Annex No. 1 to this Agreement, sent electronically or by post to the Seller's address, at the Consumer's discretion. Annex No. 1 is only a help for withdrawing from the contract and is not required for the effectiveness of the withdrawal. The Consumer may, but is not obligated to, use it. For effective withdrawal, a written statement to the Seller's address is sufficient.
6. To meet the deadline specified in point 2, it is sufficient to send a statement of withdrawal before its expiration.
7. The Seller will promptly confirm receipt of the withdrawal statement and inform the Consumer of the further procedure, including how to return costs and provide answers to any questions.

8. The Seller will promptly, within no more than 14 calendar days from receiving the Consumer's withdrawal statement, return all received payments, including any costs associated with the service. The Seller will return payments using the same payment method the Consumer used unless the Consumer explicitly agrees to another method of refund that does not incur any costs.
9. The Consumer bears only the direct costs of withdrawing from the contract.
10. The right to withdraw from the contract does not apply to the Customer in relation to contracts specified in Article 38 of the Consumer Rights Act, including in the case of: [subsections]

subsections.value: • Provision of services where the entrepreneur has fully performed the service with the explicit consent of the Consumer, who was informed before the service began that after the performance, the right to withdraw from the contract would be lost.
• Where the service includes digital elements that cannot be undone once performed.

content.value: 1. For a proper complaint submission, the Customer should provide their details, such as: name and surname or company name, address of residence or company address, email address, the subject of the complaint, the order number (if possible), the time period related to the complaint, and the circumstances justifying the complaint (a description of the issue) or any service features that are missing but were promised by the Seller or presented to the Customer.

2. If the Customer is a Consumer, in the case of the first complaint, the customer may expect a re-performance of the service or a refund. For a digital service, the Consumer can also request removal of defects in the digital service, and if the defect removal is ineffective, they may request a price reduction or withdraw from the contract. When assessing excessive costs, the value of the service free of defects, the nature and significance of the identified defect, and the inconvenience for the Customer caused by other forms of satisfaction will be taken into account.

3. Unless otherwise provided by separate provisions, the entrepreneur is required to respond to the Consumer's complaint within 14 days of receiving it. If the entrepreneur does not respond within this period, the complaint is considered accepted. The entrepreneur must provide the response in writing or another durable medium (e.g., USB drive or CD/DVD).

4. If the claim is not addressed within the prescribed period, it is considered accepted by the Seller. A claim regarding withdrawal from the contract, if not addressed within the deadline, is not considered the same as accepting a complaint.

1. Information on out-of-court complaint handling and redress procedures, and how to access them, is available at the offices and websites of municipal Consumer Ombudsmen, consumer protection NGOs, Provincial Trade Inspection authorities, and at the following UOKiK addresses: www.uokik.gov.pl/spory_konsumenckie.php, www.uokik.gov.pl/wazne_adresy.php, www.uokik.gov.pl/sprawy_indywidualne.php.
2. A Consumer may, among other options: [subsections]

subsections.value: • Request the Provincial Trade Inspector to initiate mediation.
• Apply to the Permanent Consumer Court at the Provincial Trade Inspectorate for dispute resolution (see www.uokik.gov.pl/wazne_adresy.php).
• Seek free legal assistance, e.g. from the Federation of Consumers (www.federacjakonsumentow.org.pl).

content.value: 3. For cross-border disputes, the European Consumer Centres Network can assist. Addresses: www.konsument.gov.pl.
4. Consumers may use the EU’s online dispute resolution (ODR) platform per Regulation (EU) 524/2013 at http://ec.europa.eu/consumers/odr/.
5. Using out-of-court procedures is voluntary and requires both parties’ consent.
1. The provisions of this §13 apply only to Customers who are not Consumers (i.e., professional transactions).

9. Disputes with non-Consumer Customers will be decided by the court competent for the Seller’s registered office.
